proof:
Proof. For any vertex set $S$, $\mathrm{deg}_G(S) = 2e_G(S) \sim 2\mathrm{Bin}(\binom{|S|}{2}, d/n)$. If $|S| \geq (1 - \xi)n$, then $\mathrm{E}[\mathrm{Bin}(\binom{|S|}{2}, d/n)] \geq \frac{d|S|(|S|-1)}{2n} \geq d|S|(1 - \xi - 1/n)/2$. For $n \geq 1/\xi$, this is $\geq d|S|(1 - 2\xi)/2 > (1 - \varepsilon)d|S|/2$. Use Chernoff bound to get that (the last inequality uses that $\frac{1-\varepsilon}{1-2\xi} \geq 1$),
$$ P(e_G(S) \leq (1 - \varepsilon)d|S|/2) \leq \exp\{-\frac{d|S|(\varepsilon - 2\xi)^2}{8(1 - 2\xi)}\} \leq \exp\{-dn(\varepsilon - 2\xi)^2/8\}. $$
Thus, union bounding over at most $2^n$ possible sets, the probability that exists a vertex set $S$ with $|S| \geq (1 - \xi)n$ and $\mathrm{deg}_G(S) \leq (1 - \varepsilon)d|S|$ is at most $\exp\{n[\log 2 - d(\varepsilon - 2\xi)^2/8]\}$, and by the lower bound on $d$, this is $\exp\{-\Omega(n)\} = o(1)$.
